Plans For Strike Made By
Preparations Committee;
Varied Program
TO START AT 11 A. M.
Similar Demonstrations To
Be Held Simultaneously
Throughout U. S.
APreparations for the third annual
Student Strike Against War reached
a climactic stage late yesterday as
the Student Council of the Hopkins,
in the person of its president, Meade
Johnson, declared it would support the
Strike next Wednesday and that it
would bring to trial any person found
not acting "in a gentlemanly and orderly fashion."
The declaration of the Council came
closely upon the heels of a meeting
of the Strike committee. Included in
the preparations committee were representatives of the Cotillion Board,
American [Student Union, Y. M. C. A.,
NEWS-LETTER, Hullabaloo, A. A.
Board, League Against War and Fascism, Debating Council, Tau Beta Pi,
and the Student Council. The last two
named were still acting unofficially
at the time of the meeting.
Set For Next Wednesday
The strike is set to take place next
Wednesday, April 22, at 11:00 A. M.
If present plans succeed, classes will
be suspended at that time. This will
ilttt 13'e Made definite, however, until
later in the week.
Among those who have been invited to address the demonstration
are [Senator Bennett Clark, of Missouri, chairman of the Senate Munitions Investigation Committee; the
Reverend John Hutchinson, Professor
Hubbard, head of the Physics Department, and Lt. Col. Hoisington, Professor of Military Science and Tactics, as well as several student representatives, including Bernard Lewis,
graduate student from Brown University and Rhodes scholar; Maurice
Shils, Chairman of the Strike Committee, and Herschel Halbert, regular center on the football team and
member of the Debating Council.
To Bring Up Nye-Kvale Bill
One of the major issues of the
Strike has to do with the support of
the Nye-Kvale Bill, which is due to
come up for deliberation in the House
of Representatives shortly. The measure carries the provision to make
military training optional in all colleges and places where it is now compulsory. According to Kenneth Zierler, Strike Chairman, it is proposed
to bring up at the Strike a resolution
supporting the bill.
The demonstration next Wednesday
will be but one of many to be held
simultaneously at leading schools
country.
and colleges throughout the
These strikes, which were inaugurated in 1934, have aroused increasing
interest with each passing year and
should be well-attended everywhere.
Last year more than 175,000 students
on a hundred campuses participated.

Dr. Powell Of Harvard To Give Series Of Two Lectures On
The Constitution
Thomas

Reed

Powell,

Langdell

Professor of Law at the Harvard
Law School, will give two public lectures at the Johns Hopkins University April 23 and 24. He will be introduced by the Hon. Carroll T. Bond,
Chief Judge of the Maryland Court

Dr Powell, who is probably the
leading authority in the country on
the Supreme Court and the Constitution, has selected as his subject "Some
Ways of a Written Constitution."

The Student
Council And
The Strike
The students of America are holding
their annual antiwar strike at eleven
A. M. next Wednesday. In order that
all students may witness and participate in the activities of the strike,
classes will be suspended at this time.
Every student should be consciously
aware of the fact that the administration is in the midst of an intensive
drive for funds to perpetuate the university. Any extraordinary occurrence
or happening on the camiius at this
time would be seized by reporters who
would enlarge upon the details and
such a story would be read by the very
people to whom the university is looking for financial aid. It is needless to
say that the results would be disastrous. Therefore, the Student Council
extends to every student the invitation
to attend the assemblage and to act
in a gentlemanly and orderly fashion.
The Johns Hopkins University expects
this from you.
In case there is any unusual occurrence or rioting, the Student Council
will have to bring the offenders to
trial. Examples of conduct such as was
demonstrated on the same occasion
in 1934 will not be tolerated and such
offenses will be severely dealt with.
The members of the Strike Committee are desirous of an orderly assembly and have cooperated to their utmost to promote gentlemanly conduct
and order.
It is hoped that every student will
place his university in the light in
which it should be held, and participate in the Anti-war [Strike with the
intention of seeing that it is carried
out in an orderly fashion and will not
bring condemnation down upon the
university.
Sincerely,
D. MEADE JOHNSON.

British Scholars To
Lecture On Milton
Edinburgh Professor Will
Open Poetry Lectures
At Hopkins
With the budding of nature comes
the spring. And with the spring comes
poetry, interpreted annually at the
Johns Hopkins by lecturers of the
Percy Graeme Turnbull Memorial
Foundation. Next Monday at 5 o'clock
in the Lecture Room of Latrobe Hall,
Dr. H. J .C. Grierson, professor of
Rhetoric and English Literature at
Edinburgh University, will inaugurate
the thirty-second course with five lectures on the general topic, "Milton as
Prophet and Artist." His specific subject at that time will be "(Prophetic
Poetry in the Bible," and will last for
one hour. Doors will be closed promptly at the hour scheduled.
On Tuesday and Wednesday of next
week at the same time and place, Professor Grierson will continue his lecture on "Milton, Academic Poet
and Prophet," and "Milton and Cromwell: the End of the Historical Poem."
Under similar circumstances his concluding lectures will be delivered on
Monday and Wednesday of the following week, the 27th and 29th of
April, respectively.
Professor Grierson is a distinguished
British essayist and scholar, his writings dealing with English poets having won him distinction in Anglican
critical circles. Some of his more noted
essays include "Lord Byron, Arnold,
and Swinburne," "Metaphysical Lyrics
and Poems of the Seventeenth Century; Donne and Butler," and "Classic
and Romantic."
Born in 1866 in Edinburgh, he received his bachelor's and master's degrees at King's College, Aberdeen. Dr.
Grierson holds honorary doctorates of
literature from St. Andrews and Trinity, Dublin. From 1894 to 1915 he was
professor of English literature at
Aberdeen.
Several distinguished poets have
lectured in the Turnbull Series at the
Hopkins recently and include Walter
de la Mare, T. S. Eliot, and George
William Russell.

tack In Renewal Of
Old Feud
The Blue Jays get their second and
last chance to sound off in the college
versus club lacrosse argument, when
they encounter the Mount Washington stickmen Saturday at 3 p. m. on
Homewood turf.
After having hammered against
the parsimonious defense around the
B. A. C, crease last week-end, the
Jay

attackmen

could

shoot 'em

against the gymnasium wall and feel
slightly relieved. Since, however, the
Mounts have neither a Reynolds nor
a Phil Lotz, and are not quite as impregnable as the Maroons or the
gymnasium wall, the Jays figure to
be somewhat more eloquent than they
were against their first club foe.
Too much defense was the story
last week. Chances for open shots
were so infrequent that when they
did come, Kelso Morrill's marksmen,
sort of surprised, couldn't find the
mark. Faulty marksmanship being
easily remedied, Jay followers can
look forward to a pickup in this department, and since shots should be
more frequent, perhaps, this week's
story will have a happier ending.
But while the Mounts don't measure up to the B. A. C, on defense,
their attack is quite the thing, presenting a fire-line that is extremely
difficult to repel In Jack Turnbull,
they have an invaluable team-player
and feeder. In Lorne Guild, they have
a deadly marksman who doesn't care
if he shoots one and makes one from
the center of the field. And Stieber
and McDorman at the close attack
posts contribute handsomely to the
charge.
Moreover, the clubmen are sure of
themselves, pass sharply, use their
sticks like so many gloved hands, and
break towards the net swiftly behind
effective blocking.
The Jay mentors have yet to see
their boys under fire, that is "normal"
fire. Against Dartmouth, Morrill and
Mallonee watched the Jays disport
under a sort of smolder; against the
B. A. C., they saw them battling
against what, in view of the Maroons'
defense, may be called an impassable
flame. For this reason the Jay mentors will, in all likelihood, put the
same team on the field that opened
the first two tussles, despite the fact
that a substitute or two could conceivably be advanced wihout noticeably weakening the starting ten.

Martial Ryhthms Of
Musical Rivals

Committee Approves
Hershner Cross Student
Plans For Contacting
Prospects
GYMNASIUM IS SCENE Elected Student
STERN, HEANY TO AID
Both Factions Confident Of Council Head
Success; Johnston Veteran Warrior
War has been declared!
The great conflict of 1914 was sugposed to be the war to end all wars,
but it wasn't, because here it is only
April, 1936, and the greatest battle of
all time is scheduled to begin this
Saturday.
It's the Freshman-Sophomore Battle of Music. Bubby Johnson's sizzling jazz and the sophisticated dance
rhythms of Rudy Kilian's Kadets
will meet in a fight until death on the
floor of the Hopkins [Gymnasium at
9:00 P. M. on April 18.
Pianos are being tuned, slide trombones are being polished, silver-toned
trumpets are undergoing a final inspection, for nothing must be amiss
wilen the two opposing factions meet
at the appointed hour.
Leaders Speak
Said Bubby: "I've seen a great
many wars in my day, but from what
I hear about those Kaydets, I've got
to do some tall stepping to maintain
my position in the Baltimore music
world. I'm gonna give 'em all I've
got, though; that's the best I can do."
Said Killian: "I haven't had quite
as much experience as Bubby has had
with these jazz battles, but I've got
hard-fighting men in my band, and
they won't give up the stands until
the last man is done for. We've got
some tricks up our sleeves, and I'm
looking for a victory on Saturday
night."
To Decorate Friday
The committee in charge of decorations will begin their work on Friday night, and if necessary work all
the way through until time for the
dance. "We've have a tremendous job
ahead of us if we are to carry out
the decorative scheme that we have
planned,' said Willim Wagner, a member of the committee. "The entire
ceiling of the gymnasium is going to
be covered with crepe paper, and
that's going to take plenty of time,"
he concluded.
According to John Ghinger, chairman of the joint dance committee,
advance ticket sales have been brisk,
and a large crowd is expected. He
pointed out, however, that, because of
the size of the gym floor, there will
be plenty of room for everyone to
dance.

Arts And Sciences Junior Defeats James Bradford
In Election

Students Not Compelled To
Contribute; Voluntary
Subscriptions Welcome
As an essential part of the Johns

Hershner Cross, a junior in the College of Arts and [Sciences, defeated
James Bradford for the presidency of
the.[Student Council in the general
election last week. His election followed a few days' campaign, during
which five candidates had entered the
field. Already Cross has undertaken
the duties of a member'of the Council and will be installed as head early
in May.
"I am very pleased to have been
given this honor, but due to the fact
that the composition of the new
Council will not be complete till the
end of this month," said Cross in a
statement to the NEWS-LETTER, "I
feel that I can make no statement
of policy at this time."
The retiring president of the Student Council, Meade Johnson, declared that "in my opinion and in
that of my colleagues, Hershner
Cross is an excellent choice and
should make an admirable leader
during the coming year. I have worked
with him on the Hullabaloo and have
found him very capable."
Like his predecessor in the Council chair, Cross is an activity man,
being a former news editor of the
NEWS-LETTER, a member of the Musical Club, and an associate editor of
the Hullabaloo. He belongs to no social fraternity but is a member of the
Tudor and Stuart Club.
Bradford, Cross's opponent, said,
"I am naturally sorry not to have
been elected, but I am glad that a
good man was chosen and therefore
shall support him unreservedly in his
policies next year."

Hopkins University Fund Appeal to
start officially next week, Clarence
Weimer has been appointed chairman
of the Undergraduate Committee by
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, president of the
University. Active direction of the
campaign is centered in the office of
P. Stewart Macauley, secretary of the
University. Norman Heany and Theodore Stern, both of the class of '34, are
assisting in the appeal, 'each assuming responsibility for the work of a
group of committees.
The Undergraduate Committee, appointed by Weimer, held its first meeting Monday, April 13,, in the Board of
Trustees Room in Remsen Hall. Plans
were presented and approved for the
work of this committee during the
campaign. It was decided that the
committee members will contact prospects personally, and that their visit
will be preceded by a letter explaining
the purpose of the campaign and enclosing a card by means of which contributions may'be made.
"Our policy throughout the campaign," explained Stern, speaking at
the committee meeting, "will be not
to press the undergraduate to contribute, nor to ask for contributions from
those parents who are making a sacrifice to send their sons to Hopkins."
It was added that President Bowman
especially requested that this be carried out.

A copy of the letter to be sent to
undergraduates was read at the conference, and unanimously approved by

Plans For Strike Made By
Preparations Committee;
Varied Program
TO START AT 11 A. M.
Similar Demonstrations To
Be Held Simultaneously
Throughout U. S.
APreparations for the third annual
Student Strike Against War reached
a climactic stage late yesterday as
the Student Council of the Hopkins,
in the person of its president, Meade
Johnson, declared it would support the
Strike next Wednesday and that it
would bring to trial any person found
not acting "in a gentlemanly and orderly fashion."
The declaration of the Council came
closely upon the heels of a meeting
of the Strike committee. Included in
the preparations committee were representatives of the Cotillion Board,
American [Student Union, Y. M. C. A.,
NEWS-LETTER, Hullabaloo, A. A.
Board, League Against War and Fascism, Debating Council, Tau Beta Pi,
and the Student Council. The last two
named were still acting unofficially
at the time of the meeting.
Set For Next Wednesday
The strike is set to take place next
Wednesday, April 22, at 11:00 A. M.
If present plans succeed, classes will
be suspended at that time. This will
ilttt 13'e Made definite, however, until
later in the week.
Among those who have been invited to address the demonstration
are [Senator Bennett Clark, of Missouri, chairman of the Senate Munitions Investigation Committee; the
Reverend John Hutchinson, Professor
Hubbard, head of the Physics Department, and Lt. Col. Hoisington, Professor of Military Science and Tactics, as well as several student representatives, including Bernard Lewis,
graduate student from Brown University and Rhodes scholar; Maurice
Shils, Chairman of the Strike Committee, and Herschel Halbert, regular center on the football team and
member of the Debating Council.
To Bring Up Nye-Kvale Bill
One of the major issues of the
Strike has to do with the support of
the Nye-Kvale Bill, which is due to
come up for deliberation in the House
of Representatives shortly. The measure carries the provision to make
military training optional in all colleges and places where it is now compulsory. According to Kenneth Zierler, Strike Chairman, it is proposed
to bring up at the Strike a resolution
supporting the bill.
The demonstration next Wednesday
will be but one of many to be held
simultaneously at leading schools
country.
and colleges throughout the
These strikes, which were inaugurated in 1934, have aroused increasing
interest with each passing year and
should be well-attended everywhere.
Last year more than 175,000 students
on a hundred campuses participated.

The Student
Council And
The Strike
The students of America are holding
their annual antiwar strike at eleven
A. M. next Wednesday. In order that
all students may witness and participate in the activities of the strike,
classes will be suspended at this time.
Every student should be consciously
aware of the fact that the administration is in the midst of an intensive
drive for funds to perpetuate the university. Any extraordinary occurrence
or happening on the camiius at this
time would be seized by reporters who
would enlarge upon the details and
such a story would be read by the very
people to whom the university is looking for financial aid. It is needless to
say that the results would be disastrous. Therefore, the Student Council
extends to every student the invitation
to attend the assemblage and to act
in a gentlemanly and orderly fashion.
The Johns Hopkins University expects
this from you.
In case there is any unusual occurrence or rioting, the Student Council
will have to bring the offenders to
trial. Examples of conduct such as was
demonstrated on the same occasion
in 1934 will not be tolerated and such
offenses will be severely dealt with.
The members of the Strike Committee are desirous of an orderly assembly and have cooperated to their utmost to promote gentlemanly conduct
and order.
It is hoped that every student will
place his university in the light in
which it should be held, and participate in the Anti-war [Strike with the
intention of seeing that it is carried
out in an orderly fashion and will not
bring condemnation down upon the
university.
Sincerely,
D. MEADE JOHNSON.

British Scholars To
Lecture On Milton
Edinburgh Professor Will
Open Poetry Lectures
At Hopkins
With the budding of nature comes
the spring. And with the spring comes
poetry, interpreted annually at the
Johns Hopkins by lecturers of the
Percy Graeme Turnbull Memorial
Foundation. Next Monday at 5 o'clock
in the Lecture Room of Latrobe Hall,
Dr. H. J .C. Grierson, professor of
Rhetoric and English Literature at
Edinburgh University, will inaugurate
the thirty-second course with five lectures on the general topic, "Milton as
Prophet and Artist." His specific subject at that time will be "(Prophetic
Poetry in the Bible," and will last for
one hour. Doors will be closed promptly at the hour scheduled.
On Tuesday and Wednesday of next
week at the same time and place, Professor Grierson will continue his lecture on "Milton, Academic Poet
and Prophet," and "Milton and Cromwell: the End of the Historical Poem."
Under similar circumstances his concluding lectures will be delivered on
Monday and Wednesday of the following week, the 27th and 29th of
April, respectively.
Professor Grierson is a distinguished
British essayist and scholar, his writings dealing with English poets having won him distinction in Anglican
critical circles. Some of his more noted
essays include "Lord Byron, Arnold,
and Swinburne," "Metaphysical Lyrics
and Poems of the Seventeenth Century; Donne and Butler," and "Classic
and Romantic."
Born in 1866 in Edinburgh, he received his bachelor's and master's degrees at King's College, Aberdeen. Dr.
Grierson holds honorary doctorates of
literature from St. Andrews and Trinity, Dublin. From 1894 to 1915 he was
professor of English literature at
Aberdeen.
Several distinguished poets have
lectured in the Turnbull Series at the
Hopkins recently and include Walter
de la Mare, T. S. Eliot, and George
William Russell.

tack In Renewal Of
Old Feud
The Blue Jays get their second and
last chance to sound off in the college
versus club lacrosse argument, when
they encounter the Mount Washington stickmen Saturday at 3 p. m. on
Homewood turf.
After having hammered against
the parsimonious defense around the
B. A. C, crease last week-end, the
Jay

attackmen

could

shoot 'em

against the gymnasium wall and feel
slightly relieved. Since, however, the
Mounts have neither a Reynolds nor
a Phil Lotz, and are not quite as impregnable as the Maroons or the
gymnasium wall, the Jays figure to
be somewhat more eloquent than they
were against their first club foe.
Too much defense was the story
last week. Chances for open shots
were so infrequent that when they
did come, Kelso Morrill's marksmen,
sort of surprised, couldn't find the
mark. Faulty marksmanship being
easily remedied, Jay followers can
look forward to a pickup in this department, and since shots should be
more frequent, perhaps, this week's
story will have a happier ending.
But while the Mounts don't measure up to the B. A. C, on defense,
their attack is quite the thing, presenting a fire-line that is extremely
difficult to repel In Jack Turnbull,
they have an invaluable team-player
and feeder. In Lorne Guild, they have
a deadly marksman who doesn't care
if he shoots one and makes one from
the center of the field. And Stieber
and McDorman at the close attack
posts contribute handsomely to the
charge.
Moreover, the clubmen are sure of
themselves, pass sharply, use their
sticks like so many gloved hands, and
break towards the net swiftly behind
effective blocking.
The Jay mentors have yet to see
their boys under fire, that is "normal"
fire. Against Dartmouth, Morrill and
Mallonee watched the Jays disport
under a sort of smolder; against the
B. A. C., they saw them battling
against what, in view of the Maroons'
defense, may be called an impassable
flame. For this reason the Jay mentors will, in all likelihood, put the
same team on the field that opened
the first two tussles, despite the fact
that a substitute or two could conceivably be advanced wihout noticeably weakening the starting ten.

Martial Ryhthms Of
Musical Rivals

Committee Approves
Hershner Cross Student

GYMNASIUM IS SCENE Elected Student
STERN, HEANY TO AID
Both Factions Confident Of Council Head
Success; Johnston Veteran Warrior
War has been declared!
The great conflict of 1914 was sugposed to be the war to end all wars,
but it wasn't, because here it is only
April, 1936, and the greatest battle of
all time is scheduled to begin this
Saturday.
It's the Freshman-Sophomore Battle of Music. Bubby Johnson's sizzling jazz and the sophisticated dance
rhythms of Rudy Kilian's Kadets
will meet in a fight until death on the
floor of the Hopkins [Gymnasium at
9:00 P. M. on April 18.
Pianos are being tuned, slide trombones are being polished, silver-toned
trumpets are undergoing a final inspection, for nothing must be amiss
wilen the two opposing factions meet
at the appointed hour.
Leaders Speak
Said Bubby: "I've seen a great
many wars in my day, but from what
I hear about those Kaydets, I've got
to do some tall stepping to maintain
my position in the Baltimore music
world. I'm gonna give 'em all I've
got, though; that's the best I can do."
Said Killian: "I haven't had quite
as much experience as Bubby has had
with these jazz battles, but I've got
hard-fighting men in my band, and
they won't give up the stands until
the last man is done for. We've got
some tricks up our sleeves, and I'm
looking for a victory on Saturday
night."
To Decorate Friday
The committee in charge of decorations will begin their work on Friday night, and if necessary work all
the way through until time for the
dance. "We've have a tremendous job
ahead of us if we are to carry out
the decorative scheme that we have
planned,' said Willim Wagner, a member of the committee. "The entire
ceiling of the gymnasium is going to
be covered with crepe paper, and
that's going to take plenty of time,"
he concluded.
According to John Ghinger, chairman of the joint dance committee,
advance ticket sales have been brisk,
and a large crowd is expected. He
pointed out, however, that, because of
the size of the gym floor, there will
be plenty of room for everyone to
dance.

Arts And Sciences Junior Defeats James Bradford
In Election

Students Not Compelled To
Contribute; Voluntary
Subscriptions Welcome
As an essential part of the Johns

Hershner Cross, a junior in the College of Arts and [Sciences, defeated
James Bradford for the presidency of
the.[Student Council in the general
election last week. His election followed a few days' campaign, during
which five candidates had entered the
field. Already Cross has undertaken
the duties of a member'of the Council and will be installed as head early
in May.
"I am very pleased to have been
given this honor, but due to the fact
that the composition of the new
Council will not be complete till the
end of this month," said Cross in a
statement to the NEWS-LETTER, "I
feel that I can make no statement
of policy at this time."
The retiring president of the Student Council, Meade Johnson, declared that "in my opinion and in
that of my colleagues, Hershner
Cross is an excellent choice and
should make an admirable leader
during the coming year. I have worked
with him on the Hullabaloo and have
found him very capable."
Like his predecessor in the Council chair, Cross is an activity man,
being a former news editor of the
NEWS-LETTER, a member of the Musical Club, and an associate editor of
the Hullabaloo. He belongs to no social fraternity but is a member of the
Tudor and Stuart Club.
Bradford, Cross's opponent, said,
"I am naturally sorry not to have
been elected, but I am glad that a
good man was chosen and therefore
shall support him unreservedly in his
policies next year."

Trackmen Drop
Opener Against
Garnets 75-51

V

Coach Hambleton's Outfit Is
Handicapped By Injuries And Weather
A crippled Hopkins track team
dropped its opening meet of the season to Swarthmore last Saturday.
The Jays, minus the services of several of their most able performers,
succumbed by a 75 to 51 count to
the Garnet invader in a spirited battle on the Homewood field.

The defeat came as a distinct surprise to the Black and Blue, as many
had hoped for an undefeated track
campaign. Injuries, however, and inclement weather, which prevented
practice, caused Hopkins to enter a
below full strength

Golfers Beat Haverford;
Lose To Swarthmore

combine 6 to 3, after having defeated Haverford on the previous afternoon, 8 to 1.
The contest with Haverford was
played under the worst possible conditions since the course has been
flooded by heavy rains. However, despite the handicap Bill Wagner of
the Jays was able to card a 39-3877, and his team mate, Vernon Kelly,
managed to obtain a 39-39-78. Linton
was the only Haverford man to score.
In dropping their first verdict, the
Jays managed to divide the six points
of the first two foursomes but then
Burt, Wickenhazer, and Boyer joined
to bring in the remaining points for
the victor. Miller and Dunning were
the only Hopkins golfers to gain
points for the losers.

Four star competitors, Lewis,
Sholtes, Peppler and Buc, were especially affected by these circumstances. The last two named were
unable to participate at all, while the
former pair were seriously handicapped on account of injuries and
lack of condition.
Surprisingly enough, the Jays held
their opponents almost even in the
field events, which long have been
their weak spot.
